planet.name: Lupus-TR 3b
Lupus-TR 3 b
planet.description: Lupus-TR 3b is the only planet in the system. The planet is a typical a hot Jupiter orbiting Lupus-TR 3, an early dwarf type star

planet.name: MOA-2013-BLG-220L b
planet.description: MOA-2013-BLG-220L is a microlensing event observed in 2013. The most likely candidate for the lens system is a planet orbiting a brown dwarf host star. Many of the parameters are uncertain and followup observations are required to further constrain the system. Observations will become possible in 2021 when the lens and source will have separated sufficiently to be resolved in high resolution images.

planet.name: EPIC 201596316 b
EPIC 201596316.01
K2-11 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft during its extended K2 mission, Campaign 1.

planet.name: Kepler-435 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: KOI-680 b
KOI-680.01
Kepler-435 b
KIC 7529266 b
2MASS J19290895+4311502 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the Kepler telescope and confirmed with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: OGLE-2014-BLG-0676L
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: MOA-2010-BLG-477L b
MOA 2010-BLG-477L b
planet.description: Densely covered observations of a high-magnification event led to the discovery of the planet MOA-2010-BLG-477 b. Many different telescopes around the world have been used in this collaborative effort, including a 40cm telescope in Antartica.

planet.name: OGLE-2011-BLG-0251 b
OGLE 2011-BLG-251L b
planet.description: The planet OGLE-2011-BLG-0251 b was discovered using gravitational microlensing. The host star is an M dwarf. It is located towards the Galactic Bulge. The planet lies beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models.
planet.imagedescription:
This plot shows the light curve of the OGLE-2011-BLG-0251 microlensing event. The main magnification is due to the host star, only the tiny perturbation near the peak is the signal caused by the planet.
Credit: Kains et al (2013).

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0950L b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: WTS-1 b
planet.description: The Hot Jupiter WTS-1 b is the first extrasolar planet found by the WFCAM Transit Survey. The observations were made at the 3.8-m United Kingdom Infrared Telescope and the Hobby-Eberly Telescope. The planet has one of the largest radius anomalies among the known Hot Jupiters its mass range.

planet.name: MOA-2008-BLG-379L b
MOA 2008-BLG-379L b
planet.description: MOA-2008-BLG-379Lb is a planetary mass object discovered by gravitational microlensing. Because a faint source star crossed a large resonant caustic, the planetary signal dominates the light curve. A statistical model has been used to determine the physical system parameters.

planet.name: OGLE-2015-BLG-0966L b
planet.description: OGLE-2015-BLG-0966Lb is a cold Neptune-like planet orbiting a star in the galactic disc. It is not known whether the source star of the microlensing event is located in the galactic bulge or the galactic disc, which affects the estimate of the distance and separation of the lens system. The values given here are for the case where the source is located in the bulge.

planet.name: OGLE-2011-BLG-0265L b
MOA-2011-BLG-197 b
planet.description: A cold Jupiter orbits an M-dwarf star that gave rise to the microlensing event OGLE-2011-BLG-0265. The preferred solution out of two host star/planet configurations is presented here.

planet.name: MOA-2013-BLG-605L b
OGLE-2013-BLG-1835L b
planet.description: Because of degeneracies involved in modelling the microlensing event MOA-2013-BLG-605, there are three possible models for the lens system. In the first, a 21 Earth-mass planet orbits a 0.19 solar mass star at a distance of 4.2 AU. This would make the planet a Neptune-analogue. In the second, a 7.9 Earth-mass planet orbits a 71 Jupiter-mass brown dwarf at 2.1 AU, and in the third a 3.2 Earth-mass planet orbits a 26 Jupiter-mass brown dwarf at 0.94 AU. Future observations taken when the lens system has moved sufficiently far away from the source star will be able to determine whether the stellar model is the correct one.

planet.name: OGLE-2013-BLG-0132L b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0026L b
OGLE 2012-BLG-026L b
planet.description: This multi-planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. Both planets are located beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models. Adaptive optics imaging was used to detect the flux from the host star.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0026L c
OGLE 2012-BLG-026L c
planet.description: This multi-planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. Both planets are located beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models. Adaptive optics imaging was used to detect the flux from the host star.

planet.name: OGLE-05-169L b
OGLE 2005-BLG-169L b
planet.description: The planetary signal in the microlensing event OGLE-2005-BLG-169 was confirmed in 2015 with follow-up measurements of the relative proper motion of the source and lens stars. The lens system consists of a 14.1 Earth mass planet orbiting a 0.69 solar mass K-dwarf with a projected separation of 3.5 AU. Assuming random orientation of the system, the 3D separation is 4.0+2.2-0.6 AU, locating it well beyond the star's snowline. The planet likely represents a "failed Jupiter core".

planet.name: MOA-bin-1 b
MOA-bin-1L b
planet.description: This planet has been discovered in data from the 2006-2007 MOA project by Bennett et al (2012). It is the first planetary event in which the stellar host is only detected through binary microlensing events. Note that the discovery paper has not been published in a peer-reviewed journal yet.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0406L b
OGLE 2012-BLG-406L b
planet.description: This planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. It is the first microlensing planet found by analyzing data from only a single telescope. The planet is located beyond the snow-line. Some core accretion theories favor the formation of massive planets inside the snow-line. However, planetary migration in the protoplanetary disk might explain why the planet has moved outwards.

planet.name: OGLE-2003-BLG-235L b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: MOA-2012-BLG-311 b
planet.description: This object was observed in a gravitational mirolensing event. A good mass estimate could not be obtained although the object is most likely of planetary nature. Unfortunately microlensing events are not repeatable and the planet is therefore marked as controversial.

planet.name: OGLE-2013-BLG-1721 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0724L b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: OGLE-2013-BLG-1761L b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: MOA-2011-BLG-262Lb
planet.description: The microlensing event MOA-2011-BLG-262 allows for two possible interpretations of the lens system: either it is a relatively nearby free-floating 3.6 Jupiter masses object with a 0.54 Earth mass satellite, or it is a low-mass star in the galactic bulge with a Neptune-class planet. The values given here are for the latter scenario.

planet.name: MOA-2010-BLG-353L b
planet.description: MOA-2010-BLG-353Lb is a Saturn-mass planet orbiting a low-mass star. It was discovered in archived light curve data for a microlensing event that occurred in 2010.

planet.name: OGLE-BLG-1195L b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: MOA-2011-BLG-028L b
OGLE-2011-BLG-0203L b
planet.description: MOA-2011-BLG-028Lb is a Neptune-mass planet orbiting a star in the galactic bulge.

planet.name: MOA-2011-BLG-322 b
MOA 2011-BLG-322L b
HJD 2455773 b
planet.description: MOA-2011-BLG-322 b is a giant planet which was discovered by MOA, OGLE and the Wise Observatory. These observatories form a network and conduct a second generation microlensing survey. The survey aims to discover and characterize extrasolar planets and their frequency, by means of round-the-clock high-cadence monitoring of a large area of the Galactic bulge.

planet.name: KMT-2015-1 b
planet.description: KMT-2015-1b is a Jovian planet orbiting a low-mass star, likely located in the galactic bulge. It was detected as part of the Korea Microlensing Telescope Network (KMTNet) lensing survey.

planet.name: OGLE-2015-BLG-0051L b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: Lalande 21185 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: eps Eridani b
eps Eri b
Epsilon Eridani b
Eri b
Eridani b
18 Eri b
18 Eridani b
HR 1084 b
HD 22049 b
planet.description: The planet eps Eri b has been inferred from radial velocities. The host star is active and recent studies have resulted in either non-detection of the planet (Zechmeister et al. 2013) or orbital parameters incompatible with previous solutions (Anglada-Escud & Butler 2012). The radial velocity variations may therefore be related to a stellar activity cycle rather than an orbiting planet.

planet.name: GJ 273 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: GJ 273 c
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: Kapteyn b
Kapteyn's Star b
Kapteyn's b
HD 33793 b
Gliese 191 b
planet.description: Kapteyn's star is named in honor of its discoverer, the Dutch astronomer Jacobus Kapteyn. It is visible through binoculars or a small telescope. The planet Kapteyn b is one of the oldest known potentially habitable planets. It's roughly 11 billion years old. The system contains at least one other planet, Kapteyn c, which is close to a 5:2 period commensurability. Analysis by Robertson et al. (2015) indicates that the radial velocity signature attributed to this planet is an artifact of stellar activity.

planet.name: Kapteyn c
Kapteyn's Star c
Kapteyn's c
HD 33793 c
Gliese 191 c
planet.description: Kapteyn's star is named in honor of its discoverer, the Dutch astronomer Jacobus Kapteyn. The planetary system is roughly 11 billion years old and contains at least one other planet, Kapteyn b, which is close to a 5:2 period commensurability.

planet.name: Gliese 674 b
GJ 674 b
Gj 674 b
Gl 674 b
planet.description: Gliese 674 is a pre main sequence star in the constellation of Ara.

planet.name: Gliese 832 b
GJ 832 b
Gj 832 b
Gl 832 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 832 is a star located in the solar neighbourhood in the constallation Grus. Therefore the observed planet Gliese 832 b is a good candidate for astrometric observations. In 2014, an additional planet, Gliese 832 c has been discovered.

planet.name: Gliese 832 c
GJ 832 c
Gj 832 c
Gl 832 c
planet.description: The star Gliese 832 is a star located in the solar neighbourhood in the constallation Grus. In 2014, a second planet, Gliese 832 c, was discovered in the system. It's a Super-Earth or Super-Venus, orbiting near the inner edge of the habitable zone. The large mass of the planet is likely to make the planet inhospitable. The discovery was only possible using a combination of radial velocity measurements from three different telescopes.

planet.name: GJ 682 b
Gliese 682 b
planet.description: The planet candidates orbiting GJ 682 were identified by Bayesian analysis of 49 UVES and 12 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: GJ 682 c
Gliese 682 c
planet.description: The planet candidates orbiting GJ 682 were identified by Bayesian analysis of 49 UVES and 12 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: Gliese 785 b
GJ 785 b
Gj 785 b
Gl 785 b
HIP 99825 b
TYC 6914-01943-1 b
IRAS 20122-2711 b
HD 192310 b
HR 7722 b
CD-27 14659 b
CPD-27 6972 b
SAO 189065 b
2MASS J20151734-2701585 b
LHS 488 b
planet.description: The planetary system around the star HD 192310 consists of two Neptune-mass planets and is located in the constellation of Capricornus.

planet.name: Gliese 785 c
GJ 785 c
Gj 785 c
Gl 785 c
HIP 99825 c
TYC 6914-01943-1 c
IRAS 20122-2711 c
HD 192310 c
HR 7722 c
CD-27 14659 c
CPD-27 6972 c
SAO 189065 c
2MASS J20151734-2701585 c
LHS 488 c
planet.description: The planetary system around the star HD 192310 consists of two Neptune-mass planets and is located in the constellation of Capricornus. The outer planet Gliese 785 c is at the outer edge of the habitable zone.

planet.name: Gliese 433 b
GJ 433 b
Gj 433 b
Gl 433 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 433 is a red dwarf in the constellation Hydro. The radial velocity data shows an additional signal with a period of 10 years. However, due to a strong correlation with various activity indicators of the star, it is most likely due to a magnetic cycle and not a planet. The cycle is similar to the Sun's 11 year cycle.

planet.name: Gliese 849 b
GJ 849 b
Gj 849 b
Gl 849 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 849 is a red dwarf in the constellation of Aquarius. Gliese 849 b is the inner of the system's two known planets.

planet.name: Gliese 849 c
GJ 849 c
planet.description: The radial velocity date for Gliese 849 has poor phase coverage for the orbit of Gliese 849 c, however its parameters can be better constrained by considering the dynamical stability of the two-planet system.

planet.name: Gliese 176 b
GJ 176 b
Gj 176 b
Gl 176 b
HD 285968 b
planet.description: Gliese 176 is a red dwarf located in the constellation Taurus. It has half the mass of our Sun. The planet consists mainly of rock but probably has a thick gas atmosphere.

planet.name: GJ 536
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: Gliese 436 b
GJ 436 b
Gj 436 b
Gl 436 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 436 is located in the constellation Leo. Due to tidal forces the planet Gliese 436b is expected to circularise on short timescales. It might be perturbed by an additional planet in the system.

planet.name: Gliese 436 c
GJ 436 c
Gj 436 c
Gl 436 c
UCF-1.01
planet.description: The star Gliese 436 is located in the constellation Leo. While observing the already known planet Gliese 436 b with the Spitzer Space Telescope, astronomers have discovered an additional transiting planet Gliese 436 c. The planet is also known as UCF-1.01. There might be even more planets in the system.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's concept shows what astronomers believe is an alien world just two-thirds the size of Earth. It was identified by NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope. UCF-1.01 might be the nearest world to our solar system that is smaller than our home planet.
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

planet.name: Gliese 649 b
GJ 649 b
Gj 649 b
Gl 649 b
planet.description: Gliese 649 is a red dwarf with about half the mass and size of our Sun in the constellation Hercules.

planet.name: GJ 649.02
planet.description: The radial velocity data for GJ 649 is compatible with either a single eccentric planet or a two-planet system with lower eccentricities.

planet.name: HD 3651.02
planet.description: The radial velocity data for HD 3651 is compatible with either a single eccentric planet or a two-planet system with lower eccentricities in a 2:1 resonance.

planet.name: HIP 65426
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: HD 85512 b
planet.description: The planet HD 85512 b could be potentially habitable if the planet exhibits more than 50 percent cloud coverage (Kaltenegger et al 2011).

planet.name: GJ 1132 b
LHS 281 b
2MASS J10145184-4709244 b
planet.description: GJ 1132b is orbiting a red dwarf star. The planet is three times closer to Earth than any other rocky exoplanet. Although the planet is not habitable, it is expected to be cool enough to hold on to an atmosphere. Because of its proximity to Earth, it might be possible to determine the composition of the atmosphere in the future.

planet.name: GJ 180 b
Gliese 180 b
planet.description: The planet candidates orbiting GJ 180 were identified by Bayesian analysis of 56 UVES and 31 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: GJ 180 c
Gliese 180 c
planet.description: The planet candidates orbiting GJ 180 were identified by Bayesian analysis of 56 UVES and 31 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: Gliese 179 b
GJ 179 b
Gj 179 b
Gl 179 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 170 is located in the constellation Orion. The planet was discovered with the Keck Observatory on Mauna Kea in Hawaii.

planet.name: GJ 422 b
Gliese 422 b
planet.description: The planet candidate orbiting GJ 422 was identified by Bayesian analysis of 24 UVES and 25 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: Gliese 1214 b
GJ 1214 b
Gj 1214 b
Gl 1214 b
planet.description: Gliese 1214 is a red dwarf in the constellation Ophiuchus only 40 light years away. The planet was found with a 40cm telescope and commercially available cameras. New observations from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope show that it is a waterworld enshrouded by a thick, steamy atmosphere. GJ1214b represents a new type of planet, like nothing seen in our solar system or any other planetary system currently known.
planet.imagedescription:
This image shows an artist's view of the planet Gliese 1214 b in front of its host star.
Credit: NASA, ESA, and D. Aguilar (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics).

planet.name: 51 Peg b
Bellerophon
planet.description: 51 Pegasi is a Sun-like star in the constellation Pegasus. The planet is also called Bellerophon. The lower limit for the radius is given for the limit of a perfectly-reflecting Lambert sphere.

planet.name: Gliese 317 b
GJ 317 b
Gj 317 b
Gl 317 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 317 is a red dwarf in the constellation Pyxis. So far only one planet is confirmed. There might be a second planet in the system, locked in a 4:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: HD 38858 b
planet.description: The planet candidate HD 38858 b has been shown to be an alias of the stellar magnetic cycle, which lasts 2930 days.

planet.name: HD 113538 b
planet.description: These planet parameters have been derived from ten years of HARPS data.

planet.name: HD 113538 c
planet.description: These planet parameters have been derived from ten years of HARPS data.

planet.name: HD 128311 b
planet.description: This planetary system is most likely in a 2:1 mean motion resonance. The inner planet orbits the star exactly twice during one orbit of the outer planet. This is a very stable configuration. Mean motion resonances help us to understand the formation of multiplanteray systems. The existense of this resonance is a strong indication that interactions with the protoplanetary disk migrated the planets to their current positions. A detailed analysis of the HD 128311 system shows that there also had to be non-adiabatic effects during the migration phase such as a third planet (Sandor and Kley 2006) or turbulence in the protoplanetary disk (Rein and Papaloizou 2009).

planet.name: HD 128311 c
planet.description: This planetary system is most likely in a 2:1 mean motion resonance. The inner planet orbits the star exactly twice during one orbit of the outer planet. This is a very stable configuration. Mean motion resonances help us to understand the formation of multiplanteray systems. The existense of this resonance is a strong indication that interactions with the protoplanetary disk migrated the planets to their current positions. A detailed analysis of the HD 128311 system shows that there also had to be non-adiabatic effects during the migration phase such as a third planet (Sandor and Kley 2006) or turbulence in the protoplanetary disk (Rein and Papaloizou 2009).

planet.name: HD 143761 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: HD 143761 c
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: Gliese 504 b
GJ 504 b
HIP 64792 b
HD 115383 b
planet.description: Gliese 504 b is the first directly imaged planet on a wide orbit around a G-type main-sequence star with a mass similar to that of our Sun. The planet is a gas giant, about 4 times more massive than Jupiter. It was discovered by the SEEDS survey.
planet.imagedescription:
This is an actual image of the exoplanet Gliese 504 b and its host star. It was taken by the SEEDS survey.
Credit: Kuzuhara et al. (2013).

planet.name: HD 189567 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 154088 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: 14 Her b
HD 145675 b
GJ 614 b
planet.description: The star 14 Herculis is only 59 light years away in the constellation Hercules. However, because it is an orange dwarf star it can not be seen with the naked eye. There is only one confirmed planet in the system, but a dynamical analysis suggests that they might be two planets locked in a 4:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: 14 Her c
HD 145675 c
GJ 614 c
planet.description: 14 Her c is the second companion in the system. Its properties are not yet well-constrained, though both radial velocity and direct imaging results give some constraints on its properties.

planet.name: SDSS J1110+0116
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

There might be even more planets in the system.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's concept shows what astronomers believe is an alien world just two-thirds the size of Earth. It was identified by NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope. UCF-1.01 might be the nearest world to our solar system that is smaller than our home planet.
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

planet.name: HIP 65426
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: HD 85512 b
planet.description: The planet HD 85512 b could be potentially habitable if the planet exhibits more than 50 percent cloud coverage (Kaltenegger et al 2011).

planet.name: GJ 1132 b
LHS 281 b
2MASS J10145184-4709244 b
planet.description: GJ 1132b is orbiting a red dwarf star. The planet is three times closer to Earth than any other rocky exoplanet. Although the planet is not habitable, it is expected to be cool enough to hold on to an atmosphere. Because of its proximity to Earth, it might be possible to determine the composition of the atmosphere in the future.

planet.name: GJ 180 b
Gliese 180 b
planet.description: The planet candidates orbiting GJ 180 were identified by Bayesian analysis of 56 UVES and 31 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: GJ 180 c
Gliese 180 c
planet.description: The planet candidates orbiting GJ 180 were identified by Bayesian analysis of 56 UVES and 31 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: Gliese 179 b
GJ 179 b
Gj 179 b
Gl 179 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 170 is located in the constellation Orion. The planet was discovered with the Keck Observatory on Mauna Kea in Hawaii.

planet.name: GJ 422 b
Gliese 422 b
planet.description: The planet candidate orbiting GJ 422 was identified by Bayesian analysis of 24 UVES and 25 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: VHS 1256-1257 b
VHS J125602.15-125721.7 b
2MASS J125601.83-125727.6
planet.description: VHS 1256-1257 b is a common-proper motion L-dwarf companion of a nearby red dwarf star. It is cooler than expected for a field L-dwarf, and its mass is close to the deuterium-burning limit.

planet.name: Gliese 1214 b
GJ 1214 b
Gj 1214 b
Gl 1214 b
planet.description: Gliese 1214 is a red dwarf in the constellation Ophiuchus only 40 light years away. The planet was found with a 40cm telescope and commercially available cameras. New observations from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope show that it is a waterworld enshrouded by a thick, steamy atmosphere. GJ1214b represents a new type of planet, like nothing seen in our solar system or any other planetary system currently known.
planet.imagedescription:
This image shows an artist's view of the planet Gliese 1214 b in front of its host star.
Credit: NASA, ESA, and D. Aguilar (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics).

planet.name: 51 Peg b
Bellerophon
planet.description: 51 Pegasi is a Sun-like star in the constellation Pegasus. The planet is also called Bellerophon. The lower limit for the radius is given for the limit of a perfectly-reflecting Lambert sphere.

planet.name: Gliese 317 b
GJ 317 b
Gj 317 b
Gl 317 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 317 is a red dwarf in the constellation Pyxis. So far only one planet is confirmed. There might be a second planet in the system, locked in a 4:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: HD 113538 b
planet.description: These planet parameters have been derived from ten years of HARPS data.

planet.name: HD 113538 c
planet.description: These planet parameters have been derived from ten years of HARPS data.

planet.name: HD 143761 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: HD 143761 c
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: 14 Her b
HD 145675 b
GJ 614 b
planet.description: The star 14 Herculis is only 59 light years away in the constellation Hercules. However, because it is an orange dwarf star it can not be seen with the naked eye. There is only one confirmed planet in the system, but a dynamical analysis suggests that they might be two planets locked in a 4:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: 14 Her c
HD 145675 c
GJ 614 c
planet.description: 14 Her c is the second companion in the system. Its properties are not yet well-constrained, though both radial velocity and direct imaging results give some constraints on its properties.

planet.name: 70 Vir b
BD+14 2621 b
Gliese 9446 b
HD 117176 b
HIP 65721 b
2MASS J1328282584+1346447 b
PPM 129843 b
TYC 898-1042-1 b
planet.description: The star 70 Virginis is located in the constellation Virgo and starting to evolve into the subgiant phase. It has a dust disc at 3.4 AU.

planet.name: SDSS J1110+0116
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: beta Pic b
bet Pic b
Beta Pictoris b
HR 2020 b
HD 39060 b
planet.description: Beta Pictoris is an A type star, 63 lightyears away from our own Solar System. The star is host to a debris disk and a planet. Using high spectroscopic observations, astronomers were able to measure the length of a day on bet Pic b: 8.1 hours. The planet or material in orbit around it may have been responsible for a transit-like event observed in November 1981.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the planet Beta Pictoris b. It has been optained with NACO on VLT. The star has been masked out to enable the viewer to see clearly the planet. Credit: ESO.

planet.name: 7 CMa b
7 Canis Majoris b
HD 47205 b
planet.description: This planet is orbiting the star 7 CMa and was discovered by the Pan-Pacific Planet Search (PPPS). It is the first detection from this ongoing survey.

planet.name: Gliese 328 b
GJ 328 b
planet.description: Gliese 328 b is an eccentric two Jupiter-mass planet with an orbital period of eleven years. The discovery is based on ten years' worth of radial velocity data from the Hobby-Eberly and Harlan J. Smith telescopes at McDonald Observatory, and from the Keck Telescope at Mauna Kea. It is currently the most massive, longest-period planet discovered around a low-mass dwarf.

planet.name: HD 217107 b
planet.description: HD 217107 b is a short-period gas giant, though its orbit has a longer period than the majority of hot Jupiters and is significantly elliptical. It is a member of a hierarchical two-planet system.

planet.name: HD 217107 c
planet.description: HD 217107 c is a giant planet in a long-period, eccentric orbit. It is a member of a hierarchical two-planet system.

planet.name: Gliese 221 b
GJ 221 b
BD-061339 b
HIP 27803 b
planet.description: The planets orbiting the K7 star GJ 221 were discovered using publicly available HARPS data. The dataset was complemented with high precision Doppler measurements from Magellan/PFS. The system hosts at least two planets, one hot Super-Earth and one sub-Saturn mass planet.

planet.name: Gliese 221 c
GJ 221 c
BD-061339 c
HIP 27803 c
planet.description: The planets orbiting the K7 star GJ 221 were discovered using publicly available HARPS data. The dataset was complemented with high precision Doppler measurements from Magellan/PFS. The system hosts at least two planets, one hot Super-Earth and one sub-Saturn mass planet.

planet.name: HD 114613 b
planet.description: HD 114613 b is a Jupiter analogue with a period of 10 years and a moderate eccentricity of 0.25. The planet was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Planet Search group.

planet.name: HD 97658 b
GJ 3651 b
BD +26 2184 b
HIP 54906 b
planet.description: Models suggest that HD 97658 b has a rocky core that is enveloped in an atmosphere composed of lighter elements. The planet's host star is the second brightest known to host a transiting super-Earth which facilitates folllow-up observations.

planet.name: HD 215152 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 215152 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 45184 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: CFBDS 1458 b
CFBDSIR J145829+101343 b
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the binary CFBDSIR J1458+1013AB. It was obtained with the Keck II Telescope in Hawaii. This is the coolest brown dwarf (or exoplanet, depending on the precise mass) found yet. Credit: Michael Liu (University of Hawaii).

planet.name: Gliese 3341 b
GJ 3341 b
LHS 1748 b
2MASS J05154667-3117456 b
PM 05138-3121 b
RAVE J051546.7-311746 b
planet.description: Gliese 3341 is a star with high proper motion and is orbited by a super-Earth planet.

planet.name: HD 42618 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: GJ 27.1 b
Gliese 27.1 b
planet.description: The planet candidate orbiting GJ 27.1 was identified by Bayesian analysis of 62 UVES and 50 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: BD+20 1790 b
V429 Gem b
V429 Geminorum b
2MASS J07234358+2024588 b
TYC 1355-214-1 b
planet.description: The existance of planet BD+20 1790 b was proposed first in 2010. New Bayesian analysis supports the hypothesis of the planetary companion.

planet.name: HD 96700 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 96700 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 128356 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: HD 204941 b
planet.description: HD 204941 b was found with the European High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS) which can reach sub-meter-per-second precision. The host star shows evidence for long-term solar-like magnetic cycles.

planet.name: BD-11 4672 b
planet.description: This planet has been discovered by the HARPS team using radial-velocity data gathered over ten years.

planet.name: HD 82943 b
planet.description: The planetary system HD 82943 consists of two planets in a 2:1 mean motion resonance. Both resonant angles are librating around zero. The orbital parameters are based on 10 years of radial velocity measurements with the Keck telescope.

planet.name: HD 82943 c
planet.description: The planetary system HD 82943 consists of two planets in a 2:1 mean motion resonance. Both resonant angles are librating around zero. The orbital parameters are based on 10 years of radial velocity measurements with the Keck telescope.

planet.name: HD 29021 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: Gliese 3470 b
GJ 3470 b
LP 424-4
2MASS J07590587+1523294
planet.description: The planet Gliese 3470 b is a transiting Hot Uranus orbiting a nearby M-dwarf. The planet was originally seen in HARPS radial velocity data and then confirmed to be a transiting planet. Spitzer observations show that it has a very low density.

planet.name: iota Draconis b
HIP 75458 b
HD 137759 b
planet.description: The planet iota Droconis b has a very eccentric orbit. Kanet et al (2010) report a transit probability that is higher than that of a typical Hot Jupiter in a 5 day orbit. However, the weakness of the transit signal requires space-based observations to achieve an unambiguous transit detection.

planet.name: HD 157172 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 21693 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 21693 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: EPIC 201912552 b
EPIC 201912552.01
K2-18 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft during its extended K2 mission, Campaign 1. This planet may be an interesting target for atmospheric studies of transiting exoplanets.

planet.name: HD 51608 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 51608 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 106515 A b
planet.description: HD 106515A is part of a binary system. It also shows signs of a planetary companion. The star system is almost 11 billion years old.

planet.name: BD-17 63 b
planet.description: The star BD-1763 is a K-type star in the constellation Cetus. It is five times less luminous than our Sun.

planet.name: 2MASS 0122-2439 B
2MASS J01225093-2439505 B
planet.description: 2MASS 0122-2439 B is an L-dwarf companion to the star 2MASS J01225093-2439505. The age and luminosity of the object gives a dual-valued prediction for the mass, either in the range 1213 or 2227 Jupiter masses, assuming the system is a member of the AB Doradus moving group.

planet.name: HD 32963 b
planet.description: HD 32963 b is a Jupiter-analogue planet orbiting a G-type star.

planet.name: HD 113337 b
HIP 63584 b
HR 4934 b
planet.description: The planet HD 113337 b is orbiting a bright young F-type star. An IR excess has been attributed to a cold debris disk around the star. The planet has been found with the SOPHIE spectrograph on the 1.9m telescope at Observatoire de Haute-Provence.

planet.name: HD 42012 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: eta Cet c
Eta Ceti c
Deneb Algenubi c
HIP 5364 c
HD 6805 c
HR 334 c
planet.description: The planetary system eta Ceti contains at least two planets. The planets are in, or at least close, to a 2:1 mean motion resonance. Such resonances occur naturally as a consequence of convergent planetary migration.

planet.name: HAT-P-11 b
HIP 97657 b
TYC 3561-02092-1 b
BD+47 2936 b
2MASS J19505021+4804508 b
Kepler-3 b
KIC 10748390 b
KOI-3.01
KOI-3 b
planet.description: The star HAT-P-11b is located in the constellation Cygnus. The planetary companion HAT-P-11b is in the field of view of the Kepler spacecraft. The expected temperature is 878K. The planets orbit is highly inclined.

planet.name: HD 117618.02
planet.description: The radial velocity data for HD 117618 is compatible with either a single eccentric planet or a two-planet system with lower eccentricities.

planet.name: HD 215456 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 215456 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: mu Leo b
HD 85503 b
mu Leonis b
Rasalas b
Alshemali b
planet.description: The planet mu Leo b is orbiting the K giant mu Leonis, also known as Rasalas (the northern star of the lion's head). It was found using data from the Bohyunsan Observatory.

planet.name: HD 126525 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: 2MASS J0219-3925 B
2MASS J02192210-3925225 B
planet.description: 2MASS J0219-3925 B is a low-mass L-type companion to an M-dwarf in the Tucana-Horologium association. The mass is close to the deuterium-burning limit.

planet.name: beta Ursae Minoris b
HD 131873 b
beta UMi b
bet UMi b
Kochab b
planet.description: This planet is orbiting the brighest star in the bowl of the Little Dipper. The star is K giant, 130 times more luminous than the Sun and about 130 light years away. The planet was found using data collected from the Bohyunsan Observatory.

planet.name: HD 77338 b
planet.description: The planet HD77338 b is a Hot Uranus orbiting a super metal-rich K0V star. It was discovered by the Calan-Hertfordshire Extrasolar Planet Search.

planet.name: HD 285507 b
HIP 19207 b
2MASS J04070122+1520062 b
BD+14 653 b
planet.description: HD 285507b is a Hot Jupiter that joins the small but growing list of planets in open clusters. HD 285507b orbits a star in the Hyades cluster.

planet.name: HD 103720 b
planet.description: HD 103720 is a very young star orbited by a giant Jupiter planet.

planet.name: HD 93385 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 93385 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: BD-08 2823 b
HIP 49067 b
TYC 5480-00020-1 b
BD-08 2823 b
2MASS J10004775-0931001 b
planet.description: The star BD-82823 is a K-type main sequence star in the constellation Sextans. It has only one fifth of our Sun's luminosity.

planet.name: BD-08 2823 c
HIP 49067 c
TYC 5480-00020-1 c
BD-08 2823 c
2MASS J10004775-0931001 c
planet.description: The star BD-82823 is a K-type main sequence star in the constellation Sextans. It has only one fifth of our Sun's luminosity.

planet.name: GJ 160.2 b
Gliese 160.2 b
planet.description: The planet candidate orbiting GJ 160.2 was identified by Bayesian analysis of 100 UVES and 7 HARPS radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: HIP 91258 b
planet.description: HIP 91258 is a Hot Jupiter with an orbital period of only 5 days. There is another planet in the system. However, currently only a quadratic trend is seen in the data which is insufficient to determine the second planet's properties. The planet was discovered with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: eps Tau b
eps Tauri b
Epsilon Tauri b
Tau b
Tauri b
planet.description: Epsilon Tauri b orbits a giant star in the Hyades cluster.

planet.name: HD 175607 b
planet.description: HD 175607 b is a sub-Neptune planet orbiting a metal-poor star.

planet.name: HD 175607 c
planet.description: The origin of the ~1400 day signal in the radial velocity data for HD 175607 is unclear. It may be due to an outer planet or it may be due to activity.

planet.name: AB Pic b
planet.description: AB Pictoris is a star in the constellation of Pictor. Because of its high mass, the companion could be a planet or a brown dwarf.
planet.imagedescription: This is a coronagraphic image of AB Pictoris. A planetary companion is visible on the lower left. It was obtained with NACO on the VLT with an occulting mask on top of AB Pictoris. Credit: ESO.

planet.name: EPIC 210490365 b
K2-25 b
planet.description: EPIC 210490365 b is a Neptune-sized planet orbiting a red dwarf star in the Hyades cluster.

planet.name: HD 3167 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: HD 3167 c
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: nu Oph b
planet.description: The Nu Ophiuchi system contains a pair of massive planets or brown dwarfs close to a 6:1 resonance.

planet.name: nu Oph c
planet.description: The Nu Ophiuchi system contains a pair of massive planets or brown dwarfs close to a 6:1 resonance.

planet.name: HD 984 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: GU Psc b
planet.description: GU Psc b is a comoving companion of planetary mass to the young M3 star GU Psc. The system is only 100 million years old and the wide separation of the planetary companion raising interesting questions about the system's formation history.

planet.name: HD 220773 b
planet.description: The Jovian planet HD 220773b is orbiting an F9-type star. It has a predicted displacement of 0.242mas and might be an interesting target for astrometry.

planet.name: HD 79498 b
planet.description: The planet HD 79498 b was found with 65 radial velocity observations over 7 years with the 2.7m Harlan J. Smith telescope.

planet.name: HD 108341 b
planet.description: Further data to be collected in August 2015 will result in more accurate parameters.

planet.name: WASP-69 b
2MASS 21000618-0505398 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team. It was published in a paper in October 2013.

planet.name: HD 11506 b
HIP 8770 b
BD-20 358 b
PPM 210762 b
SAO 148079 b
TYC 5858-2028-1 b
planet.description: The star HD 11506 is a yellow dwarf star in the constellation Cetus. The star hosts two planets. The inner planer was discovered by using Bayesian analysis (Tuomi et al 2009). The N2K campaign improves the data in 2014 with some further years of observations since the discovery.

planet.name: HD 11506 c
HIP 8770 c
BD-20 358 c
PPM 210762 c
SAO 148079 c
TYC 5858-2028-1 c
planet.description: The star HD 11506 is a yellow dwarf star in the constellation Cetus. The star hosts two planets. The inner planer was discovered by using Bayesian analysis (Tuomi et al 2009). The N2K campaign improves the data in 2014 with some further years of observations since the discovery.

planet.name: HD 164509 b
planet.description: HD 164509 is a metal rich G5V star with at least one planet. A linear trend in the RV residuals suggest the existance of an additional planet.

planet.name: HD 41248 b
planet.description: The planetary system HD 41248 consists of at least two planets. Both planets are most likely Super-Earths. Their period ratio is close to the integer ratio 7:5, a second order commensurability.

planet.name: HD 41248 c
planet.description: The planetary system HD 41248 consists of at least two planets. Both planets are most likely Super-Earths. Their period ratio is close to the integer ratio 7:5, a second order commensurability.

planet.name: HD 100777 b
planet.description: The star HD10077 is an orange subgiant star in the constellation Leo. A planetary companion was discovered in 2007 with the HARPS spectrograph.

planet.name: EPIC 206318379 b
K2-28 b
planet.description: EPIC 206318379 b is a validated super-Earth candidate in the K2 Campaign 3 field. The planet has a similar radius and insolation to GJ 1214 b.

planet.name: HD 207832 b
planet.description: The planetary system HD 207832 was discovered with radial velocity measurements from Keck/HIRES. It consists of two gas giants. Additional small mass planets might exists interior to planet b, according to a stability analysis.

planet.name: HD 207832 c
planet.description: The planetary system HD 207832 was discovered with radial velocity measurements from Keck/HIRES. It consists of two gas giants. Additional small mass planets might exists interior to planet b, according to a stability analysis.

planet.name: HD 66428 b
planet.description: HD 66428 b is a long-period giant planaet in an eccentric orbit. The radial velocities for the star exhibit a linear trend, indicating the presence of an additional object in the system.

planet.name: omi UMa b
Omicron Ursae Majoris b
Muscida b
UMa b
HD 71369 b
HIP 41704 b
planet.description: Discovered with precise Doppler measurements at Okayama Astrophysical Observatory.

planet.name: HD 103774 b
HIP 58263 b
planet.description: The Star HD 103774 hosts a Neptune mass planet. The star shows signs for varying activity during the nine year observing campaign. The planet was discovered with the European HARPS instrument.

planet.name: HIP 116454 b
K2-2 b
BD-00 4534 b
2MASS J23354927+0026436 b
PPM 174245 b
TYC 585-774-1 b
UCAC2 31966721 b
USNO-B1.0 0904-00582461 b
planet.description: HIP 116454 b is the first planet discovered by the Kepler spacecraft during its extended K2 mission. The planet is about two and a half times the size of Earth and only 55.2 parsec away. This makes it a top target for follow-up observations.

planet.name: 6 Lyn b
6 Lyncis b
HD 45410 b
planet.description: The star 6 Lyncis is a subgiant and 15 times more luminous than our Sun. The astrometric signature of the planet gives a best-fit inclination of 2 degrees, which would imply the object is a brown dwarf with 64 times the mass of Jupiter. Nevertheless, the error bars are large and allow for masses between 2.2 and 128.7 Jupiter masses, a range that incorporates both planetary and stellar masses.

planet.name: HD 5608 b
planet.description: Discovered with precise Doppler measurements at Okayama Astrophysical Observatory.

planet.name: HD 4732 b
HR 228 b
HIP 3834 b
HD 4732 b
planet.description: The planets in this double planetary system are orbiting an evolved intermediate-mass star. The observations were made at the Okayama Astrophysical Observatory and the Anglo-Australian Observatory.

planet.name: HD 4732 c
HR 228 c
HIP 3834 c
HD 4732 c
planet.description: The planets in this double planetary system are orbiting an evolved intermediate-mass star. The observations were made at the Okayama Astrophysical Observatory and the Anglo-Australian Observatory.

planet.name: HD 30669 b
planet.description: This planet has been discovered by the HARPS team using radial-velocity data gathered over ten years.

planet.name: HIP 11915 b
planet.description: HIP 11915 b is a candidate Jupiter-twin planet orbiting a solar-twin star. Although unlikely, the possibility remains that the radial velocity variations may be induced by stellar activity rather than an orbiting planet. No gas giants are present in the system with orbital periods below 1000 days, which leaves room for inner terrestrial planets.

planet.name: 2M1207 b
2MASS J12073346-3932539 b
planet.description: 2M1207 might be the first directly imaged extrasolar planet. However, due to its high mass it might also classify as a brown dwarf.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the brown dwarf 2M1207 and a planetary companion (lower left). It was the first image of an extrasolar planet and has been published 2004. Credit: ESO.

planet.name: WASP-80 b
2MASS J20124017-0208391 b
TYC 7038-834-1 b
BPM 80815 b
GSC 05165-00481 b
planet.description: WASP-80 b is a Jupiter-sized exoplanet but it has only half of Jupiter's mass. It has a transit depth of 3 percent, one of the largest reported so far. The transmission spectrum matches a hazy model with a temperature of 600 K.

planet.name: HD 109271 b
HIP 61300 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the European HARPS instrument. The system hosts at least two planetary companions. The architecture of this system is very similar to that of HD 698430. That might suggest that certain architectures are preferred in Nature.

planet.name: HD 109271 c
HIP 61300 c
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the European HARPS instrument. The system hosts at least two planetary companions. The architecture of this system is very similar to that of HD 698430. That might suggest that certain architectures are preferred in Nature.

planet.name: xi Aql b
Xi Aquilae b
ksi Aql b
Aql b
Aquilae b
59 Aql b
59 Aquilae b
HR 7595 b
HD 188310 b
HIP 97938 b
planet.description: xi Aql is a giant star in the constellation of Aquila.

planet.name: EPIC 206011691 b
2MASS J22411288-1429202 b
K2-21 b
planet.description: The EPIC 206011691 system consists of a pair of small planets orbiting a nearby M0 dwarf close to the 5:3 resonance.

planet.name: EPIC 206011691 c
2MASS J22411288-1429202 c
K2-21 c
planet.description: The EPIC 206011691 system consists of a pair of small planets orbiting a nearby M0 dwarf close to the 5:3 resonance.

planet.name: BD-10 3166 b
planet.description: The star BD-103166 is a K-type main sequence star in the constellation Crater. It is three times as metal-rich as our Sun.

planet.name: HIP 67851 b
HD 121056 b
planet.description: HIP 67851 b is one of the rare examples of a close-in planet orbiting a red giant star.

planet.name: HIP 67851 c
HD 121056 c
planet.description: HIP 67851 c orbits a red giant star. Currently the parameters are sufficiently uncertain that it is not clear whether or not it will be engulfed during the further expansion of its parent star.

planet.name: HD 11977 b
planet.description: HD 11977 b was the first planet confirmed to be orbiting an intermediate-mass star.

planet.name: Lalande 21185 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.

planet.name: Gliese 674 b
GJ 674 b
Gj 674 b
Gl 674 b
planet.description: Gliese 674 is a pre main sequence star in the constellation of Ara.

planet.name: Gliese 649 b
GJ 649 b
Gj 649 b
Gl 649 b
planet.description: Gliese 649 is a red dwarf with about half the mass and size of our Sun in the constellation Hercules.

planet.name: GJ 649.02
planet.description: The radial velocity data for GJ 649 is compatible with either a single eccentric planet or a two-planet system with lower eccentricities.

planet.name: HD 3651.02
planet.description: The radial velocity data for HD 3651 is compatible with either a single eccentric planet or a two-planet system with lower eccentricities in a 2:1 resonance.

planet.name: HD 38858 b
planet.description: The planet candidate HD 38858 b has been shown to be an alias of the stellar magnetic cycle, which lasts 2930 days.

planet.name: HD 189567 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 154088 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 1461 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 134060 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 134060 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 13808 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 13808 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 164595 b
BD+29 3165 b
HIP 88194 b
2MASS J18003890+2934188 b
PPM 106642 b
TYC 2103-1620-1 b
planet.description: As part of a dedicated radial velocity survey devoted to search for low-mass planets around a sample of 190 bright solar-type stars in the northern hemisphere, the SOPHIE search for northern extrasolar planets reports the detection of this warm Neptune.

planet.name: HD 150433 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 7199 b
planet.description: HD 7199 b was found with the European High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS) which can reach sub-meter-per-second precision. The host star shows evidence for long-term solar-like magnetic cycles.

planet.name: HD 137388 b
HD 137388 A b
planet.description: HD 137388 b was found with the European High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS) which can reach sub-meter-per-second precision. The planet orbits a K type star. HD 137388 appears in the literature as a binary system. However, according to Roell et al. (2012) the A and B components of HD 137388 have very different proper motions and are unlikely to be a physical binary system.

planet.name: HD 37605 b
planet.description: The planetary system HD 37605 hosts at least two planets. The inner planet is on a 55 day orbit with a very high eccentricity of 0.6767. This planet was discovered in 2004. In 2012, another planet on a 2720 day orbit was announced. In contrast to the inner planet, HD 37605 c is on an almost circular orbit. This leads to interesting speculations on the origin of the planetary system.

planet.name: HD 37605 c
planet.description: The planetary system HD 37605 hosts at least two planets. The inner planet is on a 55 day orbit with a very high eccentricity of 0.6767. This planet was discovered in 2004. In 2012, another planet on a 2720 day orbit was anounced. In contrast to the inner planet, HD 37605 c is on an almost circular orbit. This leads to interesting speculations on the origin of the planetary system.

planet.name: HD 20003 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 20003 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 70573 b
planet.description: The planet candidate HD 70573 b was not confirmed in follow-up measurements (Soto et al. 2015).

planet.name: HD 24040 b
planet.description: HD 24040 b is a massive Jupiter-analogue orbiting a sunlike star. The radial velocity measurements for the star exhibit a linear trend, indicating the presence of an additional object in the system.

planet.name: HD 209458 b
planet.description: By studying the carbon monoxide gas in the upper atmosphere with great accuracy, astronomers found evidence for a wind, blowing at a speed of 5000 to 10000 km per hour.
planet.imagedescription:
Astronomers have measured a superstorm for the first time in the atmosphere of the planet HD 209458 b. The very high-precision observations of carbon monoxide gas show that it is streaming at enormous speed from the extremely hot day side to the cooler night side of the planet.
This artist's impression shows the Jupiter-like transiting planet around its solar-like host star.
Credit:
ESO/L. Calcada

planet.name: HD 187123 b
planet.description: HD 187123 b is a hot Jupiter discovered by precision radial velocity measurements. It is a member of a hierarchical 2-planet system.

planet.name: HD 187123 c
planet.description: HD 187123 c is a long-period giant planet on an eccentric orbit. It is a member of a hierarchical 2-planet system.

planet.name: HD 167042 b
planet.description: HD 167042 b is a giant planet orbiting a subgiant star.

planet.name: HD 159868 b
planet.description: A second planet in this system has been discovered in 2012 by the Anglo-Australian Planet Search.

planet.name: HD 159868 c
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Planet Search. It is orbiting a star previously known to host one planet. After the discovery of the second planet, the reported eccentricity of the first planet changed significantly. This system is an example of how multiple-planet systems can masquerade as moderately eccentric single-planet systems.

planet.name: HD 564 b
planet.description: HD 564 is a metal poor star. The planet around this star has been discovered by the HARPS team using radial-velocity data gathered over ten years.

planet.name: HD 183263 b
planet.description: HD 183263 b is a giant planet in an elliptical orbit.

planet.name: HD 183263 c
planet.description: HD 183263 c is a massive Jupiter-analogue in a system containing an inner giant planet in an eccentric orbit.

planet.name: HD 154857 b
planet.description: HD 114613 b is a Jupiter-mass planet in a multiplanery system. A stability analysis shows that the system is stable for at least 100 million years. The planet was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Planet Search group.

planet.name: HD 154857 c
planet.description: HD 154857 c is a Jupiter analogue with a period of 9.5 years. The planet is part of a multi-planetary system and was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Planet Search group.

planet.name: HD 74156 b
planet.description: HD 74156 b is a giant planet in a highly eccentric orbit. It is the inner member of a hierarchical system of two planets.

planet.name: HD 74156 c
planet.description: HD 74156 c is a long-period giant planet in an eccentric orbit. It is the outer member of a hierarchical system of two planets.

planet.name: HD 165155 b
planet.description: Data for this planet was imported from the exoplanet.eu database.
